instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2179: What is A2179? A2179 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2020 with EMC 3302, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01958..
definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hello, I need help with this board. It worked correctly but my brother forgot the charger. I tried to connect it to a hotel USB port to charge it and it didn't turn on again.

I have checked it under a microscope but I don't see any burned or damaged components with the naked eye. With another laptop if the apple configurator detects the presence of this board.

thanks to all

omg! sorry



values only with charger (without battery):

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - 5v

threads.title: Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 2,96v"
Which pin of L7690?
Did you check diode mode ground too?

Is the machine recognized into DFU mode?

threads.title: Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
L7690 pin1 3,26v

mode ground any shortÂ´s at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>, etc..

The Apple configurator detects the board in lock mode (locking logo) but cannot put it in DFU mode.

threads.title: Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
So <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is correct.
Remember to always check voltage on the output pin of a coil from any buck-converter!

Try to force the machine in DFU with wire method.
